rationales.self_direction: He defends his community garden visits against colleagues' criticism, choosing his own pedagogical approach over test prep despite Mrs. Patterson's pushback.
rationales.conformity: He openly refuses to apologize for his 'field trip habit' despite a colleague's comment in the break room, going against the school's test-prep culture.
rationales.universalism: He insists the kids need to understand 'they're part of something bigger than standardized tests,' prioritizing environmental awareness and connection to the larger world.

rationales.tradition: He let his grandmother's voicemail go unanswered about the restaurant anniversary dinner, avoiding the call because his Cantonese has gotten rusty -- neglecting a cultural connection.
rationales.benevolence: He didn't call Grandma back despite knowing she needs help planning the 60th anniversary dinner, letting her down because of his own discomfort.

rationales.self_direction: He found a creative workaround to share his family history during the personal narrative unit while technically using the required curriculum materials.
rationales.conformity: He agreed to use the standardized curriculum as directed by the principal, following the institutional rules even while supplementing them.
rationales.tradition: He plans to bring in family photos and tell the real story of the Chinese Exclusion Act, preserving and transmitting his family's heritage to students.
rationales.universalism: He objects to the sanitized curriculum that reduces the Chinese Exclusion Act to two paragraphs, advocating for a fuller, more just account of history.

rationales.benevolence: He gave the students space to explore the idea of interconnection, letting them lead the discussion without rushing or redirecting, nurturing their intellectual growth.
rationales.universalism: The class discussion about water connecting all living things -- dinosaurs, fish, trees, people -- directly reflects his commitment to teaching that everyone and everything is interconnected.

rationales.hedonism: He bought the Chilean strawberries because he was tired and wanted something sweet, prioritizing immediate pleasure over his environmental principles.
rationales.universalism: He bought plastic-wrapped strawberries shipped from Chile in January, acting against his own teachings on sustainability and environmental consciousness.

rationales.tradition: He committed to giving the anniversary speech in Cantonese, the language of his family's heritage, with his grandmother helping him practice.
rationales.benevolence: He called Grandma back, agreed to give the speech she wanted, and is letting her help him practice -- showing up for her after previously avoiding her calls.

rationales.self_direction: He pushed for the diversity assembly for two years against institutional inertia, finally bringing his own vision to the whole school.
rationales.achievement: The assembly he spent two years advocating for finally happened successfully, with kids asking real questions and speakers genuinely engaging.
rationales.benevolence: He organized the assembly so his students wouldn't feel the loneliness he experienced as a kid with no representation, directly caring for their sense of belonging.
rationales.universalism: He brought in speakers from five different community organizations so students could 'see that the world is bigger than their own street,' promoting cross-cultural understanding.

rationales.tradition: He made dumplings with his mother for Lunar New Year, his hands remembering the folding, listening to stories about the restaurant -- maintaining family traditions and cultural practices.
rationales.benevolence: He was grateful his mother was still there to correct him, finding deep meaning in the family ritual of cooking together and hearing her stories.

rationales.tradition: He's practicing his Cantonese speech with Grandma and keeps rewriting it to capture what the restaurant means to the family and town as proof of belonging.
rationales.benevolence: A parent thanked him for showing her son that being Chinese-American is something to be proud of, reflecting the caring impact he has on his students' identity.
rationales.universalism: He articulates his mission as helping kids 'feel whole from the start' regardless of their cultural background, working to eliminate the caught-between-worlds confusion he experienced.

rationales.tradition: He's struggling to articulate sixty years of the restaurant's meaning in Cantonese, describing it as 'proof we belong here' -- preserving family and community heritage.
rationales.benevolence: He's practicing his speech with Grandma over video call, investing effort to honor what matters to her despite his rough Cantonese.
rationales.universalism: He secured a community garden grant to fix the irrigation system and expand raised beds for the school partnership, advancing environmental and community welfare.

rationales.conformity: He left the faculty meeting early for speech practice, knowing the principal noticed and wrote something down, deliberately choosing to break professional expectations.
rationales.tradition: He prioritizes the restaurant anniversary speech and honoring his family's sixty-year legacy over a faculty meeting about parking lot protocols.
rationales.benevolence: His grandmother and whole family are counting on him for the speech, and he refuses to let institutional obligations come between him and showing up for them.
